Wagner                                       Effective Management Skills and Knowledge   The Health Services Management specialization provides frameworks to understand the challenges of managing health care in a changing environment and the skills necessary to be effective in management roles. Topics include design and control in health organizations, management of service operations, the personnel function and human resources management in health settings, information systems, marketing and strategic planning.                    Required Specialization Courses         HPAM-GP.1830 , Introduction to Health Policy and Management OR HPAM-GP.1831 , Introduction to Global Health Policy                          HPAM-GP.2825 , Continuous Quality Improvement             HPAM-GP.4822 , Healthcare Information Technology: Public Policy and Management             HPAM-GP.4823 , Healthcare Information Technology for Managers             HPAM-GP.4830 , Health Economics: Principles             HPAM-GP.4833 , Health Care Management I: Control and Organizational Design             HPAM-GP.4834 , Health Care Management II: Adaptation and the Professional Manager             HPAM-GP.4835 , Principles of Human Resources Management for Health Care Organizations             HPAM-GP.4840 , Financial Management for Health Care Orgs - I: Financial Management and Budgeting                                 Capstone      All Capstone projects begin in the fall and are completed at the end of the spring semester. Full-time students who begin in the spring semester typically need 2½ years to complete their degree.                        CAP-GP.3801 , Capstone: Advanced Projects in Health Finance, Management, and Policy I             CAP-GP.3802 , Capstone: Advanced Projects in Health Finance, Management, and Policy II                                          Full-Time Faculty              Anthony     Kovner       John     Donnellan       Thomas     D'Aunno              Note   Students who plan to specialize in Management should earn a "B" or better in CORE-GP 1020 Managing Public Service Organizations and HPAM-GP 4833 Health Care Management I: Control and Organization Design. Students without previous management experience are encouraged to obtain relevant experience via internships, the Foundations for Public Service Work requirement, part time employment or the Residency Program.       Graduation and Employment Rates   96.3% of May 2013 graduates were employed within 10 months of graduation.   91% of students who entered in Fall 2008 graduated on or before Summer 2013. (NYU Wagner allows up to 5 years to complete the MPA degree.)                                    Links   Current information about Capstone sections and pre-requisites   Health Services Management Competencies Overview   Management Courses by MPSO Topic Area                                                                              © NYU Wagner   295 Lafayette Street, New York, NY 10012-9604   212.998.7400   Copyright and Fair Use   Contact Us   Sitemap   New York University

Policy and Management by U.S. News and World Report     NYU Wagner's Health Policy and Management program has been recognized as one of the best in the country. Located in a school of public service rather than in a medical or public health school, our program crosses traditional boundaries, linking management, finance, policy, and providing students with the cutting-edge concepts and skills needed to shape the future of health policy and management.   Students receive a set of tools and experiences that allow them to understand both the delivery of health care services and the broader social, cultural, and economic factors that influence health outcomes. Our students experience firsthand the importance of health care delivery and health promotion in one of the most interesting, diverse, and complex cities in the world, and our graduates work in every sector of the health care system. Students study the key factors that explain the unequal distribution of health and disease in the world, particularly in developing countries, and the modes of intervention to improve global health.      Business Process Improvement                       Project Management                       Toolkit                                                                        Program Services           The Program Services Office (PSO) is:       A service center for project management, business process improvement, business change management and service delivery redesign across NYU’s administrative systems and services.   A liaison between administrative functions and Information Technology.   A strategic partner in developing the vision and roadmap for administrative systems and services across the Global Network University (GNU).                                                  PSO Projects & Initiatives          The PSO is currently involved in a number of the University's administrative systems initiatives and projects.              UDW+   The University Data Warehouse Plus (UDW+) is a program aimed at establishing decision support services around reporting and analytics. Over time, the UDW+ will replace the current University Data Warehouse architecture.  ServiceLink  The ServiceLink initiative seeks to transform the user experience and administrative services for the NYU Community across the GNU. The multi-phased project also involves the implementation of ServiceNow, a new tool to create and manage requests.  Procure-to-Pay (Lighthouse)    The Procure to Pay Project (Lighthouse) will transform how NYU buys, pays and manages goods and services across the University Community. This transformation will be accomplished by improving the user experience through greater visibility to transactions, reductions in paper based processes and replacement of unsupported technical solutions and platforms.  Position Management  Leveraging capabilities in both UDW+ and PeopleSync, this initiative will provide members of the University with the ability to plan, manage and report on academic and non-academic positions in the Position Management staffing model with a much greater level of clarity and visibility.
